DIV1.P: Occasion'd by the lamented Fate of Viscount George Augustus Howe, Baron of Clenawley, &c.
Who was Slain in the Battle near Carillon, July the 6th, 1758.
Together with an ODE, ON THE Reduction of LOUISBOURG, July 27, 1758.

Q.L: Qui terram inertem, qui mare temperat

DIV1.P: NEW-YORK: Printed by Parker and Weyman, 1758.

DIV1.HEAD: Advertisement.
DIV1.P: THE two following Odes were compos'd on their respective Oc∣casions, merely for the Author's Amusement and the Entertain∣ment of his Friends; but their Importunity and favourable, not to say partial, Judgment of them, have induc'd him to present them to publick View, not without some Hope, that they may meet with a kind Reception, if not by their intrinsick Merit, at least by their Re∣lation to those important and interesting Events which gave them Birth.

As the Life of Lord HOWE was unspeakably valuable, so his Death is, and it were astonishing if it were not, most sincerely and universally lamented: And indeed I know not, whether the sad Ca∣tastrophe which succeeded his Fall, tho' attended with the Loss of so many Lives, has occasion'd more Regret, than the single Fate of that illustrious and promsing young Hero. But the Reduction of Louis∣bourg to his Britannick Majesty must needs give inexpressible Pleasure, and afford a most delightful Prospect, to every one, in proportion as he apprehends its Importance to, and prizes the Welfare of, the Bri∣tish Colonies in America,

In this View of Things, and a critical Humour apart, the Au∣thor hopes these Performances with all their Faults (which he is ig∣norant of) may afford a pleasing Entertainment to his Fellow Subjects, even at this Distance of Time; and if so, he wou'd have been glad if his Distance from the Press, &c. had not prevent∣ed their being somewhat more seasonable.

If the Character of Lord HOWE be, as doubtless it is, incompleat it must be consider'd that this Sketch of it was copied from the Voice of Fame; and if any Gentlemen of the Army or Navy seem to be neg∣lected, or not mention'd according to their Rank, in the Ode on the Reduction of Louisbourg, I hope it will be imputed rather to the Ignorance than the Partiality, of

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: COME, weeping Muse, descend and bring
Thy well-known Lute, thy doleful Notes renew,Refering to some former Compositions occasioned by publick Misfortunes.
With trembling hand strike each complaining String,
(Thy drooping Brows crown'd with funereal Yew)
And in soft plaintive Numbers sing
The hapless Fortune of the Brave,
The cruel Triumphs of the Grave,
With pensive Strains attend his Herse,
And crown his Mem'ry with a grateful Verse.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Come all ye gen'rous Souls that know,
What tis to feel a patriot Woe,
Whose Countries Losses make your Sorrows rise,
Whose Bosoms bleed when Valour dies,
Describes a Loss so formidably great,
Give your soft Passions vent, and all disolve in Woe.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: From distant Lands the Hero came,
His heart all glowing with a sacred Flame
By no mean mercenary Hopes inspir'd,
But bent on a disinterested Aim,
To save our sinking Country from the Jaws of Fate.
To try the Chance of martial Strife,
And all the Dangers of the raging Main;
Danger and Toil in vain oppose his Way,
Our northern Regions to his View display
Their frightful Wilds beheld him nobly dare,
Bound forth impetuous to the War,
Nor dread the awful Horrors of the wild Campaign.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: Noble without a Thought of Pride,
HOWE well cou'd lay the Pomp of Life aside
And fare as meanly as the rural Swain;
Tho' bred in all the Elegance of Taste,
Th' unmanly Softness of the Age,
Nor wou'd he be a Guest
The British Int'rest all his Care,
Refus'd the Pleasures of the sparkling Bowl,
And quench'd his Thirst in the pure chrystal Flood.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: Vice in our Army long had held
And Guilt enormous with a fouler Stain
Than crimson Seas of Blood, or Myriads of Slain.
Till, shock'd by Crimes of monstrous Size,
The blushing Goddess, forc'd to yield,
And fled, a erst Astrea, to her native Skies.
But when kind Providence from far
Call'd HOWE, her Vot'ry, to the Field of War,
There she resum'd her former Throne,
There, in the midst of Arms,
And clad the fav'rite Youth in glories like her own.
The Dictates of the heav'nly Maid,
And taught his Legions to confess her Sway;
And, by his great Example struck with Awe,
Forsook the hallow'd Camp, or shunn'd the Face of Day.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: Others cou'd plan the future War,
And triumph o'er the yet unconquer'd Foe:
Modest tho' valiant, and tho' youthful wise,
Young HOWE cou'd shine in Council too;
But he had Hands as well as Voice,
While others talk'd with mighty Noise,
The active HOWE was form'd to DO.
How glow'd with Love and Wonder every Heart,
When in each Toil he bore a Part,
In ev'ry Danger led the Way!
How did his great Example fire each Breast,
When he abridg'd his Hours of Rest,
And in continual Labours worried out the Day!
Such were the Warriors of the Days of old,
Heroes like these extensive Vengeance hurl'd
Had spoil'd the Temper of her Arms;
By Thunderbolts like these she once subdu'd the World.

LG.HEAD: VII.
LG.L: If Heav'n had deign'd to spare
And put a period to the doubtful War:
We fondly hop'd to see thy Sword
Deal sudden Vengeance on the Foe,
We hop'd to see our Rights restor'd,
And shout thee living and victorious home;
But ah! our pleasing Dreams are o'er,
Our flatt'ring Prospects are no more,
Our Hopes are buried in thy Grave,
Where is the Man, lamented HOWE!
Like thee to head our Army now,

LG.HEAD: VIII.
LG.L: But check thy passions, Muse, and tell
How clos'd a Life employ'd so well,
How brave the Hero fought and how divine he fell.—
Behold! with what a noble Mien,
And bold as the fam'd Marlbro was,
His Sword the ardent Warrior draws,
Inspiring with new Life his martial Bands,
Till the dire Ball, aim'd with delib'rate Art,
By some base Villain guiltier than the rest,
Down sinks the Hero to the Ground,
And as he falls he cries,
"Fight on my Friends, and trust the Skies,
"Nor let your Courage languish, tho' your Leader dies;
"No; save your Country, and revenge my Death."—
He can no more.—Fate stops his Breath,
His Spirit issues in a Flood of Gore,
And HOWE, the great, the good, the valiant, is no more.

LG.HEAD: IX.
LG.L: Curse on the Wretch, that aim'd the fatal Ball!
And can ye, Britons, see your Leader fall
No, give the Wretch the Fate he gave,
Let him not triumph o'er the Brave;
But feel just Vengeance for an Hero slain.—
His Crime recoils upon his Head,
And down the Villain drops, to wait upon his Shade.

LG.HEAD: X.
LG.L: But Thee, dear Youth, long shall thy Country mourn,
With grateful Tears bedew thy Dust,
And future Ages, to thy Mem'ry just,
Shall dress with Glory thy distinguish'd Urn:
Long as these Regions know th' insulting Gaul,
America shall still deplore thy Fall;
And shine with Honour in the Rolls of Fame.

DIV1.HEAD: An ODE, On the Surrender of Louisbourg, July 27, 1758.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: At length the destin'd Blow is giv'n;
Our Cause is still the Care of Heav'n.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: The Palm to the victorious Foe,
When Waves can roll or Winds can blow?

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: And gracious Heav'n at length repays
And bids us hope for happier Days.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: Nor vainly glory in your Towr's;

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: With your bold Taunts insult the Brave;
"France in her turn has fed the Grave.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: No more regret our late Alarms;
Now sing the Power of British Arms.

LG.HEAD: VII.
LG.L: And give your smiling Country Joy.

LG.HEAD: VIII.
LG.L: And aid the Triumphs of my Song.

LG.HEAD: IX.
LG.L: Who deigns to make our Land his Care,
The Lord of Hosts the GOD of War.

LG.HEAD: X.
LG.L: 'Tis He that makes our Sages wise;
And the Counsels of the Skies.

LG.HEAD: XI.
LG.L: He bids its raging Billows rise;
And all the mighty Tumult dies.

LG.HEAD: XII.
LG.L: That sweeps along the watry Wasle;
Or sends the furious Northern Blast.

LG.HEAD: XIII.
LG.L: Well wast our mighty Squadrons o'er;
Hnd reach at length the hostile Shore.

LG.HEAD: XIV.
LG.L: Rides out the Siege in solemn State;
To save her Louisbourg from Fate.

LG.HEAD: XV.
LG.L: By Force to ward the dire Alarms;
To check the Progress of our Arms;

LG.HEAD: XVI.
LG.L: The Sov'reign Mistress of the Flood:
The Fleet that boasts a Guardian-God.

LG.HEAD: XVII.
LG.L: And fires amid the wild uproar;
Fearless they climb the rocky Shore▪

LG.HEAD: XVIII.
LG.L: In all their dreadful Horrors rise;

LG.HEAD: XIX.
LG.L: Fear and Confusion on the Foe;

LG.HEAD: XXI.
LG.L: Come and address the Pow'r supreme;
And shout loud Honours to his Name:

LG.HEAD: XXII.
LG.L: Like Clouds of Incense to the Skies.

LG.HEAD: XXIII.
LG.L: "How dreadful is a GOD in Arms!

LG.HEAD: XXV.
LG.L: "Thine is; and be the Glory Thine.—

LG.HEAD: XXVI.
LG.L: Our Chiefs, those mighty Bolts of War,
And save the People of his Care.

LG.HEAD: XXVII.
LG.L: And prudent Zeal, Unus qui nobis cunctando restituis Rem.
Such Rays as grace the Hero's Name.

LG.HEAD: XXVIII.
LG.L: And all grow great in Britain's Cause.

LG.HEAD: XXX.
LG.L: Their Deeds with Honour shall rehearse▪
Their Names embalm'd in lofty Verse.

LG.HEAD: XXXI.
LG.L: Their Praise in rural Songs begin▪
And dress their Brows in living Green.

LG.HEAD: XXXII.
LG.L: Your thankful Thoughts and Tongues employ,
Britons, and give a Loose to Joy.

LG.HEAD: XXXIII.
LG.L: And far resound each Hero's Name:

LG.HEAD: XXXIV.
LG.L: And savage Nations dare no more
